==Is ethics futile?==
    −
The whole assumption of the field of ethics is that agreement is possible.
+
A central topic in the philosophy of ethics has been the role of reason.
−
And since agreement is possible, ethics is possible.
      −
The term ''ethics'' is actually derived from the ancient Greek ''ethos'', meaning ''[[moral character]]'' [http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=ethics]. ''Mores'', from which ''morality'' is derived, meant social rules or etiquette or inhibitions from the society. In modern times, these meanings are often somewhat reversed, with ethics being the "science" and morals referring to one's conduct and character. But it is significant that the origins of the words reflect the tension between an inner-driven (character) and an outer-driven (conduct) view of what constitutes morality.<!--How is this paragraph ''on-topic'' here?-->
+
Can reason alone ever be a motivating force? -- Hume said it is only ever the "slave of the passions", while Kant purported to derive his [[deontological ethics]] from pure reason.
    −
== The origins of Ethics ==
+
Can we reach, through reason, an ethics that is in some sense "objective", or, at the opposite extreme, are we doomed to [[moral relativism]]?
  +   +
Various twentieth century philosophers and movements have presented arguments that downplayed the role of reason: for instance, logical positivism, in arguing for [[emotivism]], tended to write off ethical language as literally meaningless; and Jean-Paul Sartre, in "Existentialism is a humanism", presented a moral dilemma that he claimed reason was unable to resolve.
  +   +
== The origins of ethics ==
     
When did ethics begin and how did it originate? If we are referring to ethics proper -i.e., the systematic study of what we ought to do- it is clear that ethics can only have come into existence when human beings started to reflect on the best way to live. Virtually every human society has some form of myth, religion, to explain the origin of morality. This link between [[morality]] and [[religion]] has been so firmly forged that it is still sometimes asserted that there can be no morality without religion. According to this view, ethics ceases to be an independent field of study. It becomes, instead, [[moral theology]].
